issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares Pneumatic.raisePressure(pressure: double) (problem_statement.md lines 16-19), but elsewhere the problem text/remarks and the solution use an int parameter (remark refers to raisePressure(int pressureIncrease) at problem_statement.md line 71, and solution_repository/src/de/tum/in/ase/Pneumatic.java declares raisePressure(int)). This parameter-type mismatch (double vs int) is an inner- and cross-artifact inconsistency that will confuse students: if they implement the interface according to the UML (double) their code/signature will not match the provided solution/tests (which expect int), causing compilation/test failures or incorrect submissions.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the raisePressure parameter type consistent across all artifacts. The simplest fix (and the one aligned with the reference solution) is to update the UML and problem text to use an int parameter: change the UML signature to raisePressure(pressureIncrease: int): void and update any textual mentions to use int. Alternatively, change the solution and any remarks to use double if the intent is to work with double precision, but ensure all three artifacts (UML, textual remarks, template, and solution) use the same type.

issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares Pneumatic.raisePressure(pressure: double): void (parameter named 'pressure' of type double), but the solution implements raisePressure(int pressureIncrease) (parameter named 'pressureIncrease' of type int) in the Pneumatic interface and the implementing classes (LaunchedDropdownTower, LaunchedRollerCoaster). This mismatch (parameter name and — more importantly — parameter type) creates a mapping/confusion for students: they will expect to declare/implement raisePressure(double) as specified by the UML, but the provided solution code uses a different signature. The type difference may also cause compilation or test mismatches if students follow the UML exactly.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the Pneumatic.raisePressure signature across artifacts. Prefer updating the interface and implementations to match the UML: declare void raisePressure(double pressure) in Pneumatic and change the implementing methods in LaunchedDropdownTower and LaunchedRollerCoaster accordingly (use the parameter name 'pressure' to match the UML). Alternatively, if int is intentional, update the UML/problem statement to use int and name 'pressureIncrease' so all artifacts use the same signature. Consistent signatures will remove unnecessary cognitive/compilation issues for students.
